messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Springsteen is a famous singer from America.  
He writes and sings songs.  
Many singers who sell a lot of albums stop making new songs.  
But he is different.  
His new songs are still number one in music charts.  
Many people go to big stadiums to see him.  
He is still very good.  
He is almost seventy.  
It does not surprise me at all.  
He tells us basic stories about ourselves.  
We listen to 'Born in the USA'.  
The stories are still true today.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure and Fidelity Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7222 is below the required 0.75. The BERTScore of 0.8553 is below the required 0.90.
- The phrase "best-selling album artists" was simplified to "singers who sell a lot of albums," losing the specific industry nuance.
- "Stadium-filling new music" became "big stadiums to see him," weakening the original impact.
- "Remains at the top of his game" turned into "still very good," removing the sense of sustained excellence.
- "Our most fundamental stories about ourselves" was reduced to "basic stories about ourselves," losing depth.
- "As relevant today as they ever were" was paraphrased to "still true today," diminishing emphasis on enduring relevance.
Suggestion: Restore the original lexical items and structure. Use "best-selling album artists," "stadium-filling new music," "remains at the top of his game," and "our most fundamental stories". Keep "as relevant today as they ever were" intact. This will improve semantic fidelity and raise both MeaningBERT and BERTScore to acceptable levels.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Springsteen is a famous singer from America.  
Many best-selling album artists stop writing new songs.  
But Springsteen is different.  
He remains at the top of his game.  
He is still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music.  
He is almost seventy.  
It does not surprise me at all.  
He tells us our most fundamental stories about ourselves.  
We listen to 'Born in the USA'.  
The stories are as relevant today as they ever were.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: CEFR Compliance. Classifier rated B1. The text exceeds the A2 level in multiple ways. - The word relevant is B1 level and not allowed at A2. - The word fundamental is B2 level and must be replaced. - The word remains is C1 level and too advanced. - The clause It does not surprise me at all is too complex; A2 uses simpler structures. Suggestion: Replace relevant with important or true, fundamental with basic, remains with stays. Break complex sentences into shorter ones. Use only and, but, so, because as connectors and limit vocabulary to the provided A2 list.

Text saved: 'Springsteen' is the last name of Bruce Springsteen.  
He is a singer from the USA.  
He is a best-selling artist.  
Unlike many other best-selling artists, he still makes chart-topping, stadium-filling new music.  
He remains at the top of his game in his late 60s.  
It doesn't surprise me at all.  
He tells us important stories about ourselves.  
When you listen to Born in the USA, you hear these stories.  
They are as important today as they ever were.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: CEFR Compliance. Classifier rated B1. The output uses B1-level structures and vocabulary that exceed A2. Evidence:
1. The clause "Unlike many other best-selling artists, he still makes chart-topping, stadium-filling new music." uses the comparative word "Unlike" and hyphenated compounds, both beyond A2.  
2. The sentence "When you listen to Born in the USA, you hear these stories." uses a subordinate when-clause, a B1 structure.  
Suggestion: Rephrase into short, independent sentences. Remove "Unlike many other..." and replace with a simple statement. Eliminate hyphenated adjectives like "chart-topping" and "stadium-filling." Use only simple connectors such as "and" or "but." Split subordinate clauses into separate sentences.
